Thanks Rob! I really loved this course! I was happy, this course didn't start with explain what is javascript, node, express.... insted it jumped into the details. 
The only things I missed are the recommendations for production apps like: use async middlewares as much as you can + use an async handler as wrapper around your async middleware to avoid using try-catch in every middleware, exception handling recommendations for nodejs and express, using process managers for increasing performance....

I liked the speed and the details of  lectures and that it mostly focused on it's topic 'Express'. I recommend this course everyone, who needs a practical usage and details of express.  Great job Rob!

results.content:
A few things about this course that may help someone in the future. Note the date in case this course gets updated and this review is no longer valid. I'm on a mission to absorb everything I can find on Express and MongoDB/mongoose so when I queried the site for intermediate and expert courses this appeared under intermediate. First I'll point out this isn't technically an intermediate course this is a beginner course on Express. Personally I would think anyone looking to get into Express should understand Node and that they should feel comfortable in Node but that might be me. The first three courses I did watch on maxed playback. 

Onto the reason for the rating.

-1 star: The whole course it was mentioned the importance of securing API keys and he even went on to mention in the last video there are scrapers just looking for keys on Github. I think there is a missed opportunity here to teach the importance of env files and how it's important to not push keys to a repo. Even a simple use case for something like dotenv with a .gitignore is better than nothing in Express 101, 201 or 301.

- 1/2 star: This might be due to completing a lot of the other courses or since I've already gone through every LinkedIn course on Node but the repo is just a dump of everything. I would have preferred a branch approach where I could code along and if my code failed I could reference the source files for comparison from that branch. This approach would also help if I ever forget something and need to come back and do a video, for example passport, I could download those starting files and code along with the video. Wouldn't even have to use Github some other authors just provide a file download for that lesson.

-1/2 star: Maybe this is another personal preference but over the time taking the course I recall him mentioning the importance of not overloading a file and separating certain routes. I think this same logic should be applied to middleware. The author dumped all middleware into the same files as the routes when I think it would have been better to create a directory and then require the middleware into the route. I think this is a best practice so feel free to take it as personal preference.

I do like to ask a few questions to see if the author will apply. Some Udemy course I've taken the author is MIA for some time and that can be reflected in the Q&A but the questions I did ask the author responded within 24 hours so that should be noted. This review can be changed and the cool thing with Udemy courses is authors can modify their course so it be nice to see that implemented.

I think the author has a lot of potential to make an awesome true intermediate or expert course. I've only taken one other course on Udemy that does truly feel like an intermediate/expert course but I would love a singular, full blown project, from beginning to deployment that covers Node, Express, MongoDB, mongoose, Handlebars, passport, stripe, Jest, ESLint and Heroku and the author is welcome to ask what I'm referring to. I will be following the author to see what other courses they create.

response.content:
Thanks for leaving your thoughts, Chewie! I agree that taking an express course neccessitates node knowledge which is why I try and keep it focused on express. env, and .dotenv are node and Linux concepts. in production I would pass them as process variables and keep them out of the codebase entirely. It might only take 10 minutes to explain, but that's true for every back end topic, so I eliminate everything I can to keep on task.
Repo and code organization are certainly up to the user. I've changed every course I've released and it never seems to meet demand; If you've found someone you really like, hammer those courses home! Good luck.

results.content:
I really enjoyed Robert Bunch's style of teaching; very thorough, repetitive, and comprehensive on a focused topic. I like how the instructor uses the npm module docs as a checklist to the course contents. He's given me better appreciation for 'RTFM'. I now read the docs, look at dependencies,  git likes and the node_modules folder.

The course covers everything about Express including templateing, authentification and DB connections. The examples are used perfectly to lead into real use cases. This course has made me a better developer.

I've taken a dozen IT courses on Udemy this year and there are many great instructors but Robert Bunch is among the best.

results.content:
This guy Robert not only knows his stuff, but at the end of his course, you too can say you know your stuff. He shows that he understands that knowing “how” simply isn’t enough. He’s responsive, and extremely supportive in getting you from point A to B. Honestly, I just got lucky when I found this course when I did because I was on the edge with Express. I simply could not understand it so I was getting ready to settle for being an average developer. I’ve tried multiple courses on here from top instructors, teamTreehouse, Pluralsight, and frontEndMasters(which is extremely good) and everyone of them were telling me HOW to do xyz, but none were explaining the WHY behind anything around the MEAN stack. They just take you by the hand and drag you through the MEAN stack and at the end you end up feeling crappier than before because the only thing you’ve learned is that you can’t do anything without a tutorial. Most instructors try to teach you everything at once because it’s a lot easier than it is to explain one technology in a way that could enable students to leverage the tool. Robert on the other hand, took one tool and get’s you to understand the ins and outs of that technology. 

He just released his other course and I’ve never looked forward to learning any technology from a specific instructor until now. I’m so excited to step in his next course because I know the content is worth every dime, every hour, and more. A whole lot more.

Thank you so much, Rob. Now that I feel extremely comfortable in express, I’m hoping one day you’ll release other parts of the MEAN/MERN stack. You are by far the best instructor I’ve ever had the chance to take a course from on this platform. Again, thank you so much!

results.content:
So far I have only completed the express301 section and have the following comments

Pros:
- Pace thus far is great. Builds the justification for using express really well, let's see how it evolves as the course progresses
- The instructor deliberately makes the effort to explain by directly pointing out how his explanation of the concept is tied to the code he is writing which helps in understanding what a method call or function is achieving conceptually
- Love the fact that the instructor takes the time to delve into a each topic and explain it as thoroughly as possible. Coding along also helps, I personally try to code it side by side into a totally different app so that I can be sure I understand all the concepts.

Cons:
- Distracting jokes and confusing examples. The instructor makes needless commentary that provides zero instructional value rather distracts the audience.
- The editing is not great, the video randomly skips mid-sentence. I checked and it's not because of any glitch, the video has been edited in that manner, and that's just lazy.

results.content:
I've rated this as 4.5 stars on the following basis: 
teacher/teaching style:  Robert is a very knowledgeable guy, clearly an experienced teacher from both the pacing and coverage and depth of material. 

Audio/video production: No issues here at all. Solid. Professional grade course. 

Material: All the bases are covered, the depth is appropriate. The knowledge you would want to gain is what you will gain and more. 

The projects:  This is where I've knocked off half a star. Another movies project is not that engaging or likely to be a key portfolio piece. I can see why it makes sense from a teacher's perspective, it's universal, it's a real project that is not too daunting to a beginner and so on. To some it's another movies project. So very minor gripe on the creativity of the project subject matter, but understandable for the purposes of being open to the widest audience. 

Would I recommend: Yes, the key sales pitch of this course is that most courses cover express as an also ran and teach you to use it without much understanding of it, or why it might be like that. With that in mind and given the quality of production and delivery it made for a highly enjoyable and informative course. 

Lecturer / TA responses to the support section:  I only posted a couple of questions and advisories where I found resolution to my own broken code. Robert replied himself - that's a nice touch.

closing words: Udemy is a platform where anyone can claim to be a tutor - but real tutors stand out. Robert deserves to be in that crowd that stands out from the rest. You wont have wasted your money.

Just auditing the course and highly impressed with structure of course and how Robert has kept it well focused on Express. Robert is one of the very good instructors on this platform. 
Some Areas of improvement for this course : 
1. Robert should slow down when he is going thru concepts that are critical for learners. At times, Robert has just gone lightning fast over certain middleware and taken too long time in explaining under-the- hood concepts, i don't think it is a good approach as it confuses the newbie learners of Express. 
This course should be labelled as advanced Express. 
2. Please stop your habit of writing too long comments in code,  
I agree your comments are great in re-enforcing important concepts. But please try to shorten them.
Keep up the good work.

results.content:
Robert nailed this course. Seriously, WOW! I'm taken back with how great of a teacher and presenter he is. When his other course goes on sale, I'm going to buy it.

Robert went very slow, he took his time, and he covered each topic multiple times. He speaks clearly. Sometimes he says funny things.

Compared to other courses, I particularly liked that this one is not 28 hours long. I'm so tired of seeing these massive 28+ hour courses that try to cover every topic that exists in the world. I especially despise those courses that spend that entire time building on one single code base, that quickly becomes impossible to keep track of in our minds. (Andrew Mead, Stephen Grider and Brad Traversy are famous for this)

Robert does NOT do that. Robert keeps restarting with simple boilerplate code and focusing on specific topics at a time. This might be why the topics have stuck with me so far. (Another instructor who is really good about this is Asim Hussain)  
*At the end you do build a little project, but it's still small enough to grasp.

So what will you learn?
A little about networking (tcp/udp/http), express, the http methods, cookies, query parameters, templating engines (pug/ejs/handlebars), helmet, path, middleware (making your own too), http headers, making routes, the express generator package, different content-types, serving static files from a directory, sending/downloading images with a link, some chrome devtool tips, how to accomplish simple server + routing without using express (using the 'http' module)

What will you not learn (at the time of writing) that you might expect to find?
- How to structure a large project with best practices
- How to authenticate the routes that you make (with passport)

At the end of the course, I feel like I can:
Set up a nodejs server that can either serve pages or api endpoints on any path, via any HTTP method. Pages can use server side rendering with ejs. I can read/write cookies and parse query parameters. I can receive data via the body of POST submissions. I can take some steps towards securing my web application with helmet. I can write my own middleware.

More important than what I can now do, is what I now know. I feel like I can explain how a lot of this actually works (was built) to someone else.

results.content:
I like that that this 'Before Express'  video mentioned how so many courses use Express mixed with other things and there's no focus on HTTP. I'm a junior developer without a CS degree, so I have some knowledge gaps. I determined that HTTP and the request and response cycles are what I know least about. I can't tell you how many times I've done unit tests, and mongo, and mongoose, and react, and node through courses and had no emphasis on how HTTP actually works. I'm finally at the point where I'm tired of not knowing HTTP,  same-origin requests, cross-origin requests, and what headers I need.

After hitting halfway:
I'm still enjoying it quite a bit. I've learned lots of the  little things I've seen before but didn't take the time to understand or try to use.

Every lesson was well organized and informative.  Lessons naturally build upon each other, they give you room to grow your skills and practice your skills. Very well-done course.

results.content:
I feel the course did a good job of covering different aspects of Express.js, and feel the instructor did a good job of starting with the background of how transport protocols, HTTP, and HTTPS work.

I think the way the instructor handles exercises could be a little better. I am glad that the instructor includes the exercises in the body of the videos. Based on experiences with other instructors, I find it helpful if the instructor mentions that an exercise is going to be coming up. I think it would also help if there were more exercises, and the exercises were larger. For example, instead of "see if you can figure out how to get this parameter", try asking students "get this parameter we are passing in and send it back in the response".

Otherwise, I feel this course was well designed, and very helpful in conveying the subject.

results.content: Hi Robert, I have done a number of courses on Udemy as well as other sites and I have to say that this was by far the best to date. What I really appreciated is that you take the time to explain the concepts before you get into the code, something many other courses fail to do. As a result you actually understand what you are writing when you code, rather than just follow along. Thanks for greating a AAA+ course. I'd highly recommend it to other students interested in building a solid understanding of Express!
